p._value:
openssl-pkcs12
- PKCS#12 file command

PKCS#12 output
(export) options:

_values:
This command
allows PKCS#12 files (sometimes referred to as

files) to be created and parsed. PKCS#12
files are used by several programs including Netscape,

There are a lot
of options the meaning of some depends of whether a PKCS#12
file is being created or parsed. By default a PKCS#12 file
is parsed. A PKCS#12 file can be created by using the

option (see below). The PKCS#12 export

and encryption passwords: most software always assumes these
are the same so this option will render such PKCS#12 files

_values:
Use legacy mode of operation
and automatically load the legacy provider. If OpenSSL is
not installed system-wide, it is necessary to also use, for
example, "-provider-path ./providers" or to set
the environment variable

to point to the
directory where the providers can be found.

In the legacy
mode, the default algorithm for certificate encryption is

cipher is enabled in the build. The
default algorithm for private key encryption is 3DES_CBC. If
the legacy option is not specified, then the legacy provider
is not loaded and the default encryption algorithm for both
certificates and private keys is

This option specifies that a
PKCS#12 file will be created rather than parsed.

This specifies filename to
write the PKCS#12 file to. Standard output is used by
default.

Standard input is used by

that refers

certificates are present they will also be included in the
PKCS#12 output file.

If this option is present then
the certificate chain of the end entity certificate is built
and included in the PKCS#12 output file. The end entity
certificate is the first one read from the

file
if no key is given, else the first certificate matching the
given key. The standard

used for chain building, as well as any untrusted

An input file of untrusted
certificates that may be used for chain building, which is
relevant only when a PKCS#12 file is created with the

option is given
as well. Any certificates that are actually part of the
chain are added to the output.

This specifies the
"friendly name" for the certificates and private
key. This name is typically displayed in list boxes by
software importing the file.

p._value:
Add the "Local Key
Set" identifier to the attributes.

_values:
Specifies that the private key
is to be used for key exchange or just signing. This option
is only interpreted by

software. Normally "export
grade" software will only allow 512 bit

keys to be used for encryption purposes
but arbitrary length keys for signing. The

option marks the key for signing only. Signing only keys can
be used for S/MIME signing, authenticode (ActiveX control
signing) and

client authentication,
however, due to a bug only

and later
support the use of signing only keys for

These options allow the
algorithm used to encrypt the private key and certificates
to be selected. Any PKCS#5 v1.5 or PKCS#12

section for more information). If
a cipher name (as output by "openssl list
-cipher-algorithms") is specified then it is used with
PKCS#5 v2.0. For interoperability reasons it is advisable to
only use PKCS#12 algorithms.

p._value:
Special value
"NONE" disables encryption of the private key and
certificates.

_values:
By default the private key and
the certificates are encrypted using

unless the ’-legacy’
option is used. If ’-descert’ is used with the
’-legacy’ then both, the private key and the
certificates are encrypted using triple

This option specifies the
iteration count for the encryption key and

To discourage
attacks by using large dictionaries of common passwords the
algorithm that derives keys from passwords can have an
iteration count applied to it: this causes a certain part of
the algorithm to be repeated and slows it down. The

is used to check the file integrity but
since it will normally have the same password as the keys
and certificates it could also be attacked.

iteration counts are set to 2048, using
these options the

and encryption
iteration counts can be set to 1, since this reduces the
file security you should not use these options unless you
really have to. Most software supports both
iteration counts so it needs the

This option is included for
compatibility with previous versions, it used to be needed
to use

iterations counts but they are now
used by default.
Do not attempt to provide the
integrity. This can be useful with the

algorithm and cannot be
supported by the

Although there
are a large number of options most of them are very rarely
used. For PKCS#12 file parsing only
need to be used for PKCS#12 file creation

options
are present then all certificates will be output in the
order they appear in the input PKCS#12 files. There is no
guarantee that the first certificate present is the one
corresponding to the private key. Certain software which
tries to get a private key and the corresponding certificate
might assume that the first certificate in the file is the
one corresponding to the private key, but that may not
always be the case. Using the

option will
solve this problem by only outputting the certificate
corresponding to the private key. If the

certificates are required then they can be output to a
separate file using the

algorithms allow the
precise encryption algorithms for private keys and
certificates to be specified. Normally the defaults are fine
but occasionally software can’t handle triple
encrypted private keys, then the option

can be
used to reduce the private key encryption to 40 bit

complete description of all algorithms
is contained in

p._value:
Prior 1.1
release passwords containing non-ASCII characters were
encoded in non-compliant manner, which limited
interoperability, in first hand with Windows. But switching
to standard-compliant password encoding poses problem
accessing old data protected with broken encoding. For this
reason even legacy encodings is attempted when reading the
data. If you use PKCS#12 files in production application you
are advised to convert the data, because implemented
heuristic approach is not MT-safe, its sole goal is to
facilitate the data upgrade with this command.

_values:
Parse a PKCS#12
file and output it to a

p._value:
openssl pkcs12
-in file.p12 -out file.pem

Output only
client certificates to a file:

openssl pkcs12
-in file.p12 -clcerts -out file.pem

Don’t
encrypt the private key:

openssl pkcs12
-in file.p12 -out file.pem -noenc

Print some info
about a PKCS#12 file:

openssl pkcs12
-in file.p12 -info -noout

Print some info
about a PKCS#12 file in legacy mode:

openssl pkcs12
-in file.p12 -info -noout -legacy

_values:
Create a
PKCS#12 file from a

file that may contain
a key and certificates:

p._value:
openssl pkcs12
-export -in file.pem -out file.p12 -name "My
PSE"

Include some
extra certificates:

_values:
Export a
PKCS#12 file with data from a certificate

file containing a
key, with default algorithms as in the legacy provider:

p._value:
openssl pkcs12
-export -in cert.pem -inkey key.pem -out file.p12
-legacy
